comments.body: This was the one component for which I ended up writing custom truncation logic, since there's no API for specifically customizing the style of each legend item (direct links to API docs on the recharts website are weirdly broken, but see http://recharts.org/ --> Api --> Legend). An alternative would be overriding the `content` property of `Legend`, but that seemed a bit heavyweight / I didn't want to reimplement rendering the Legend's contents for MLflow (I'd basically have to reimplement some of [this logic](https://github.com/recharts/recharts/blob/master/src/component/DefaultLegendContent.js))

diffHunk:

              <CartesianGrid strokeDasharray="3 3"/>
              <Legend verticalAlign="bottom" payload={this.getLegendPayload('line')}/>
              <YAxis/>
              {runUuids.map((uuid, idx) => (

comments.body: Creating objects in `mapStateToProps` makes it so you can never use PureComponent to optimize rendering. Every time redux store updates, this will create a new `runNames` object (and `metrics` object), which will cause shallowEquals of props to be false, triggering a render. Going forward you might want to calculate derived data in a selector, so it can be memoized with [reselect](https://www.npmjs.com/package/reselect).
Got it, made https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/425 to track this
The wrong use of "string" here was causing a React error to be logged before
This was also causing a React warning that the items in a list did not have distinct keys
